7.body: Concrete is highly alkaline and fairly hostile to molds. 9.author: patri70
9.body:
So roots pull moisture from soil which causes a cavity or collapse under the foundation. Roots do not destroy the foundation by growing into concrete. A root barrier forces the root to grow away from the foundation and that it doesn't then pull moisture from the soil directly under the foundation. Roots may grow in cracks of plumbing. Root barrier may help move roots grow away from plumbing.

Once a crack appears due to subsistence, roots can grow in between cracks. A good example of plastic working is a root bound container pot of a tree in the garden center. Roots don't bust out of the container. Once a large root is cut, only smaller roots grow so it more manageable by something like plastic. Once a large root is cut, it doesn't just grow another large root pushing out everything.

9.author: ministerofinteriors
9.body: Large tree roots over time will often topple retaining walls and lift pavement and concrete sidewalks. I'm not really sold on the idea that a root barrier is going to stop such a large tree.

9.author: patri70
9.body:
To install a root barrier, the existing root needs to be cut. What grow out of that cut root is small roots which are more manageable. 

If a root barrier were installed before a large root is under a foundation, then the small roots that have not gotten big will be pushed down away from barrier. Once pushed, the tree is kinda "trained" to grow down and away.

Roots loft sidewalks because there's an expansion joint. Once lifted, they can grow between cracks. Retaining ways let moisture through which means roots can grow between crevices. If retaining walls do not let moisture through then the wall will be supporting water in addition to soil.

Texas A&M study on root barriers: https://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/newsletters/hortupdate/hortupdate_archives/2002/mar02/art3mar.html

9.author: ministerofinteriors
9.body:
That's not a study, it's a description of what a root barrier is. Also poured concrete isn't impervious to movement from roots. 


We'll have to agree to disagree on this. I wouldn't literally bet the house that a root barrier will solve this issue.

You'll need to clean it off the wood assuming it's not rotted.  If it hasn't gotten any worse for months, you probably just need to clean it.  Watch a few youtube videos on removing mold, wear proper protection, mask, goggles, and clean properly.  
Also, mold doesn't die, it goes dormant, for basically eternity.

13.author: distantreplay
13.body: Restricted size can restrict *flow*, which though it will not change the static pressure delivered from the city, will reduce performance at the point of use. It would be helpful to know what material the pipe is made of.

13.author: One_has_no_name_
13.body: It's mostly copper. There is one galvanized pipe also.

13.author: distantreplay
13.body: The location of the galvanized and whether it has been electrolytically isolated from the copper may be important. Galvanized steel pipes more than thirty years old can become very severely restricted with internal corrosion. This effect is accelerated if the galvanized is allowed to be direct electrolytic contact with copper. When water flows through metal pipes a very weak electrical current is created because of the presence of magnetically polar ions present in the water. Since galvanized steel has a lower electrolytic potential compared to copper, if the two differing metals are allowed to conduct this very weak current causes the steel lose surface electrons to match the potential of the copper. This loss of electrons causes the galvanized coating to gradually decompose into a thick, black scale that chokes the inside of the pipe. This same process can happen even if the galvanized is not indirect contact with copper (it's how the galvanized coating protects the underlying steel from rust). It just happens more slowly. For that reason most engineers consider the service life of galv steel supply pipe to be no more than 40 years.

19.author: CountryAssLawyer
19.body:
What climate do you live in? Have you tried removing the outlet and the bathroom fan to take photos behind those wall penetrations?

You likely want to hire a home inspector who is capable of inspecting HVAC, among other things. Many things could be wrong with your house at this point. For example, if water isn’t coming into your house from outside, could the dynamics of your house be creating condensation within your building envelope? 

Check out Home Performance on YouTube. Two of their recent videos highlight a homeowner of a new house that had mold issues caused by a poorly designed HVAC system. Not saying that is your problem, but it demonstrates the kinds of things that can go wrong.

19.author: CountryAssLawyer
19.body:
It’s interesting that you mention it was very cold for a day or two. If you have a new and otherwise airtight house, cold temperatures, especially mixed with a storm, could cause condensation in parts of your building envelope that are not airtight enough. 

For example, blowing wind could cause air to move through small hole in your house not unlike sucking on a straw. The warm, humid air in your house could then move through various cavities, find a cold surface, and condense to water. If this is the case, it’s not a huge issue, but you’ll want to better air seal those penetrations soon to prevent this issue in the future because the last thing you want is water accumulating in walls over time and causing mold or rot to specific areas of your new home.

19.author: CountryAssLawyer
19.body:
https://www.buildingscience.com/documents/digests/bsd-108-investigating-and-diagnosing-moisture-problems

This may actually be more relevant to you than the videos. Good luck.

20.author: skeptibat
20.body:
Do you have two switches? or was it just a two-bulb fixture?

If the latter, dig the wires out from behind the mount, and you'll find that the extra white and extra black are just pigtails going to a wirenut, and you can safely remove them.

22.body: Ok, so as long as there's no leaking inside the house, it is likely that just the bib might be compromised, or all good and doesn't need to be replaced?

22.author: skeptibat
22.body:
Yeah, if no leaks, no leaks. 

I should probably mention that while brass is ductile, it can be work hardened. Repeated expansion can make it brittle, and one winter it might crack. (Think about a piece of wire or a paperclip... it bends back and forth, but if you keep doing that, eventually it will break)

They make anti-syphon/anti-freeze bibs. These extend 6" (or more) into the wall and the actual sealing valve is inside the house instead of outside.

22.author: vvampxx
22.body: This hose bib has one of those anti-syphon things on the end, but I know it's not the type you're talking about. Would the type of anti-syphon device on my hose bib done anything during the freeze to relieve pressure?

22.author: skeptibat
22.body:
Nah, they're basically just one-way valves meant to prevent water in a hose from entering your house plumbing. I mentioned the anti-syphon part faucet because they often go hand-in hand.

I think the technical term for what I'm referring to is frost-free or freeze-free.

24.author: distantreplay
24.body:
Unless they are very carefully planned and implemented as part of a comprehensive design for a cold roof system, powered attic fan ventilators often create problems rather than solve them. They have a known, intentional effect of depressurizing attic air spaces. Without a very well designed system of unobstructed outside air intake vents they can pull a vacuum on the ceiling membrane and produce a flow of warm, moist air from the  indoor heated spaces of the home. 

This is both wasteful of energy year round, but it also can result in rapid moisture damage to the structural wood framing in the attic. Warm moist air pulled into the attic under vacuum during winter rapidly cools on contact with cold wood framing. And water condensate then forms on those surfaces feeding structural decomposition.

33.author: unnamedhuman
33.body:
Then it's poor surface preparation. It means they didn't dig the ground out properly flat to prep for the sidewalk, or whatever that is, and your feeling the top of a dirt mound where the concrete was thinly applied over top. The concrete likely broke apart and washed away immediately at the top of the dirt mound where the concrete was thinnest.

Thing is, concrete needs several inches of thickness to retain its structural integrity. If they didn't prep it properly in the beginning, you'll never get it right now. That whole thing likely needs torn up and redone if you want a quality lasting product.

TNSTAAFL - you get what you pay for. I don't think you want this company doing any more "work" for you at all. Especially "uncompensated work."

My house is 103 years old. Depressurization is a feature not a bug.

42.author: DeltaAlphaGulf
42.body:
[Here](https://www.energyvanguard.com/blog/3-problems-with-atmospheric-combustion-inside-the-building-envelope/) is a more focused article on the topic.

Regardless of your setup you should make sure you have CO monitors near any combustion appliances and at least one per floor of the house. I would recommend you use a wired one with battery backup but more than that one with a digital display that tells you the actual readings in ppm. They can also be combination units that do CO and smoke detection. Kidde and First Alert seem to be consistently well regarded brands.

You asked about 'heavy duty stuff'.  What refrigerator is 'heavy duty'?  Read its nameplate rather than get emotional.

You discussed surge protector.  Not recommended for reasons provided.  Two completely different devices are called power strips.  One with surge protector parts is strongly discouraged.

47.author: RampantAndroid

48.author: AK12thMan
48.body:
Several of our doors have drywall cracking from the corners like this, but it's a result of thermal expansion/contraction, house settling, and seismic activity - we live in southcentral Alaska.  It's usually just from stress placed on the drywall between the door frame and the beam and can be fixed with some caulk and paint.  Or if you really want to go nuts you can cut the crack out and fix the drywall with drywall patch, mesh tape, or something similar.  It's usually not something structural, but as the other poster noted, keep an eye on it, especially if it expands or comes back after the fix.

Depending on where you live, drywall cracks are just a fact of life.

Though I'm just a homeowner with an unfortunate amount of experience fixing drywall (because the stupid earth won't stop quaking here), not a professional.

48.author: Gabebach
48.body: I do live in Southern California and actually felt my first earthquake last week! And where we live has extreme temperature swings (could be in the upper 30’s at night, then lower 70’s the next day). And the drywall is new. So hoping all of this means that it’s not a big concern, but will monitor it.

48.author: AK12thMan
48.body:
Sounds like you should be alright, especially if the drywall is new.  If the drywall was older with the house mostly settled, and no recent issues had occurred like thermal effects or minor seismic activity, then it might be more concerning.  But likely the house moved in someway and the drywall wasn't sure if it wanted to tag along so it cracked due to the pressure between the door frame and the beam.

How strong was that first earthquake and how'd you react to it?  Haha, I remember feeling my first EQ when I first moved to Alaska about 15 years ago and it completely freaked me out!  Now I barely register anything below a 5.0 and only get concerned if it goes on for longer than 10 seconds.  We had a 7.1 back in November of 2018 that seemed to go on forever (though I think it only lasted 30-45 seconds) and did quite a bit of damage across southcentral AK though - including several 10s of thousands of dollars in damage to my house.  Not a fun day.

48.author: Gabebach
48.body:
Wow! I can’t imagine that frequency. 

This was only a 3.8, centered about 100 miles away. I heard something move in the cabinet and felt a little rumble in the counter I was leaning on. Lastly 2-3 seconds tops. Honestly would’ve thought it was just old house things if I didn’t find out there was a quake nearby at that exact minute.

48.author: AK12thMan
48.body:
Hopefully the EQs stay in that magnitude for you - or even better, no EQs at all!  Smaller ones can be kind of thrilling but they get old fast haha!

That 2018 EQ had aftershocks (some of them M5-6 on their own) that went on for MONTHS, it was nuts.  Right after that, we had a bunch of articles in the paper comparing that EQ to the 1964 Good Friday quake (M9.2), which destroyed much of the southcentral area.  That EQ went on for over 4 1/2 minutes!!!  I can't even imagine...

Anyway, good luck with the repair.  With a little patience, you should be able to blend the fix in pretty well since it looks pretty hairline.  Cheers!

67.author: comfysnail
67.body: Also HEPA has filtration levels so look into that as well when deciding.

67.author: Gobucks21911
67.body:
Definitely HEPA and *not* ionic or uv type. HEPA filters are what hospitals use. It also needs to be fixed right, so pay attention to the square footage posted on the manufacturer’s page. I prefer Honeywell and, while still not cheap, they’re more reasonably priced than many competitors. 

You’ll need to replace most HEPA filters yearly and, if it has a charcoal prefilter, those every 90 days.

67.author: Gobucks21911
67.body: A true HEPA air cleaner (not furnace filter) is always 99.97% effective. If it’s not, it’s not a true HEPA filter.

67.author: comfysnail
67.body: Correct, but there are also different MERV levels which filter out different particle sizes! Higher MERV filters out smaller particles.

67.author: Gobucks21911
67.body: Yes. We use a MERV 13 in our furnace. OP was a asking about an air cleaner though, so I wanted to make sure they understood the difference. Apples to apples ;)

75.author: distantreplay
75.body: Wall ventilation fans for bathrooms exist. They are generally more expensive, there are fewer options, and they can be considerably more complicated to install. The biggest factor driving installation difficulty and expense is the type of exterior siding. Masonry veneer, stucco, metal, and exotic rain screen siding can offer some huge obstacles and may require a bit of expertise. The critical thing is often first evaluating the exterior siding and access to the wall from the outside. Then selecting a fan kit with exterior flashing and weather protection that is appropriate for that type of exterior siding.

75.author: Due_Lengthiness_5690
75.body: It’s white vinyl siding, was hoping there would be an exhaust cover similar to a driver vent cover that can just be installed over the pipe.  But the consideration to flashing and weatherproofing helps for sure

75.author: distantreplay
75.body:
There is no duct. These fans vent directly through the wall. The exterior side grill is equipped with dampers, some flashing, and some kind of mounting flange. But it is part of the fan and much larger than a small, 4 inch vent hood.

I've only installed a few. When I have I've installed as if installing a new window into an existing wall. Interior wall finishing is removed, exterior siding is removed, and rough opening framing is installed into the wall cavity to support the exterior sheathing and siding, the interior finishing, and the fan itself (along with power). Then the exterior side fan grill is mounted to the sheathing, sealed with exterior sealant, flashed with tape woven correctly into the WRB, and finished with a drip cap, before siding is restored. Basically like installing a very small flange mounted vinyl window into an existing wall. If it's happening at a second story scaffolding is required.

Lastly, if you do go with hard pipe you should still use a small section of flex duct to connect the hard pipe to the dryer to account for dryer movement.

81.body: From what I can see in the picture, it looks like there is some condensation running down the side, but some more pictures would be helpful. Also, is the furnace not turning on at all? Or not blowing hot air? A few more details on what's happening will help.

81.author: undrestimatedbanana
81.body: So I just discovered there has been water coming through that rusted hole when the washer runs, and then the furnace won't turn on at all.

81.author: claw046
81.body: Not good, but at least we're learning more. Washer and furnace should not be connected in any way, so if the washer leaks when running, maybe a leak in the white PVC pipe drain above the furnace somewhere? When it hits some electrical component in the furnace, it could lock the furnace out from starting until it dries out. Then when the thermostat calls for heat again, it could work for some time. At least until you do laundry again. Soon enough, the leaking water will burn out something or multiple electrical components in the furnace.

81.author: undrestimatedbanana
81.body: So what should I do? Check the PVC pipe? And if it's not that? I have no idea what I'm doing so any help is appreciated!

81.author: claw046
81.body: Where is the furnace located? Is the picture from you looking up at the furnace or from the side, I can't tell. I'm trying to determine what could be leaking into the furnace, if something is leaking onto it.

81.author: undrestimatedbanana
81.body: It's in the basement and this picture is looking up at it.

81.author: claw046
81.body: If the washer drain is leaking, you need to stop it. Start the washer and follow the PVC drain. Feel around any joints to see if it's wet if you can't see it leaking. You may have to wait until the washer starts draining too

83.author: super-sonic-sloth
83.body: Did you completely remove the hinge plates? Sounds like you did and in taking them off and putting them back on they shifted in the screw holes, screw placement or alignment. Also two things I doubt you sanded enough for the thickness of two coats of paint and more likely when you painted the hinge side cutouts you didn’t cutout the pooled paint in the corners. I bet if you look at the hinge plates there crooked 1/8” by resting on a pool of dried paint in the morticed corners. Take a razor blade and cut out this little bit should work better. Also next time leave the hinge plates on and mask with tape it’s how the pros do it.
